Evensong - Evensong [1973] {2010 Beatball LP MINIATURE} (FLAC.CUE)



Even by Ã¢â‚¬Å“lost gemÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ standards, EvensongÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s eponymous debut should really have fared better. Long prized by folk collectors, it was neither critically nor commercially successful. Distilling their collective influences Ã¢â‚¬â€œ mainly Dylan, Paul Simon and the ISB Ã¢â‚¬â€œ into an idiosyncratic and lively mix, Tony Hulme and Mick Lawson created a minor folk masterpiece. The addition of hired hands like BJ Cole and Herbie Flowers contribute to a rich, polychromatic record that gets you from the first listen.

The acoustic whimsy of the opener DodoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s & Dinosaurs and others such as Store Of Time and the narcissistic Firefly are exactly what one would expect to hear on a lost folk record from this period. But the majority of the other songs arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t. The hypnotic Gypsy, the dust-kickinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, Rum Runner and, the recordÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s masterpiece, the anthemic Borderline (about a young British Soldier in World War I) make this album a large, baroque-fashioned cut above.

The wealth and quality of the bonus material herein, including their odd final single, a cover of Neil YoungÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Dance Dance Dance, complete a rich and rewarding Evensong picture.
